figure_1.title: Fig. 1.
figure_1.caption: The flowchart illustrates the process of data selection and analysis for elderly Asian breast cancer patients.

claims.sentence: Subsequent exclusions included 1062 patients with undocumented chemotherapy status and 192 patients with missing survival data, yielding a final analytical cohort of 47,868 eligible participants (Fig. 1).

Moreover, the RT group manifested substantially enhanced short- and long-term survival rates, with 1-year (98.5 % vs. 93.3 %), 3-year (94.0 % vs. 84.6 %), and 5-year (88.9 % vs. 76.8 %) survival probabilities (Fig. 2A), consistently in favor of the RT-treated patients.

Nevertheless, considering the limited number of patients receiving non-beam radiation therapies, these findings require cautious interpretation and warrant validation in larger prospective studies (Fig. 2B).
Within this context, we systematically evaluated the association between primary tumor site and OS in the selected SEER cohort (Fig. 3A–B).

As shown in Fig. 4A–F, RT conferred significantly greater survival outcomes in both ER-positive (ER+) and PR-positive (PR+) patients compared to their ER-negative (ER-) and PR-negative (PR-) counterparts.
Our analysis of RT outcomes across different age strata revealed consistent survival benefits in all age groups (Fig. 5A).
Notably, despite concerns regarding treatment tolerance in advanced age, the oldest subgroup exhibited the most pronounced survival improvement (Fig. 5B–C).
To clarify this, we performed a stage-stratified analysis comparing overall survival between RT-treated and non-treated cohorts (Fig. 6A–D).

Subsequent exclusions included 1062 patients with undocumented chemotherapy status and 192 patients with missing survival data, yielding a final analytical cohort of 47,868 eligible participants (Fig. 1).

Moreover, the RT group manifested substantially enhanced short- and long-term survival rates, with 1-year (98.5 % vs. 93.3 %), 3-year (94.0 % vs. 84.6 %), and 5-year (88.9 % vs. 76.8 %) survival probabilities (Fig. 2A), consistently in favor of the RT-treated patients.

Nevertheless, considering the limited number of patients receiving non-beam radiation therapies, these findings require cautious interpretation and warrant validation in larger prospective studies (Fig. 2B).
Within this context, we systematically evaluated the association between primary tumor site and OS in the selected SEER cohort (Fig. 3A–B).
